Nonlocal web traversal or inference attacks try to retrieve information about pages linked to web pages of interest such as the inter-page relationships available on the web. Information leaks are selectively retrieved without leaving a trace of the real attacker behind. “Whenever you go on the Internet you are vulnerable to anyone from a snooper to a terrorist” (Daniel Solove 2007). Typically, nonlocal web traversal covers both the outlinks and inlinks of a given page. For inlinks, the retrieving technique is referred to as a forward search. The forward search can be limited to link targets that were available in a given release of the crawled version of the web such as the year 2000 or 2000 data dump. For outlinks, the retrieving technique is the reverse search, which retrieves pages to a target page based on “the pages that link to the target” (Abhe & Wu 2003).
